question: Question_A_07
statement:
Find the inverse of the matrix

\[\begin{bmatrix}
1  &  2\\
1  &  1
\end{bmatrix}\].
sols:
We see from the hint that the formula for an inverse of $2\times{2}$
matrices of the form

\[A=
\begin{bmatrix}
a  &  b\\
c  &  d
\end{bmatrix}\]

is

\[A^{-1}=\frac{1}{\text{det}(A)}\begin{bmatrix}
d  &  -b\\
-c  &  a
\end{bmatrix}\].

In this example we have

\[A=\begin{bmatrix}
1  &  2\\
1  &  1
\end{bmatrix}\]

and so

\[\displaystyle{}\text{det}(A)=1-2=-1.\]

Therefore we have that

\[A^{-1}=-1
\begin{bmatrix}
1  &  -2\\
-1  &  1
\end{bmatrix}
=
\begin{bmatrix}
-1  &  2\\
1  &  -1
\end{bmatrix}.\]
hints:
There is a formula for the inverse of a $2\times{}2$ matrix in the form

$A=\begin{bmatrix}
a  &  b\\
c  &  d
\end{bmatrix}$

which is

\[A^{-1}=\frac{1}{\text{det}(A)}\begin{bmatrix}
d  &  -b\\
-c  &  a
\end{bmatrix}.\]

If you can compute the determinant of A then the inverse can be written
down immediately.
